answers.answer: I have never heard of this eather.  Dr.'s here usually send you to the hospital to talk with a specialist but you are not admitted.  How far along are you?  Were you having problems for them to test you so early?
i was the one who asked them to test for it because everyone had diabetes in my family..

It would be very unusual, indeed.  Unless you failed it so badly they feel you need insulin?  But even then, most women can get the teaching they need as an outpatient.Tell your doctor you simply can't afford it.  Ask WHY you can't get the teaching done as an outpatient.
It sounds a little extreme to admit you.  Did they tell you what your sugar levels were??  I can't imagine why they can't teach you what to do as an outpatient.  Good luck to you!! :)

they will admit you originally to level out your blood sugars and teach you how to eat.  in early pregnancy erratic blood sugars can cause m/c so its probably adviseable to be admitted and apply for state aid if you have no ins.

It is normal to be admitted... they need to level out your blood sugar (and they do that with a controlled enviroment)then they teach you how to regulate it on your own to keep it stable for the rest of your pregnancy. irratic blood sugars are harmful to the fetus so they just want to get it under control.

I failed my test too, never ever did they say anything about admitting me.  I would call and talk to your doc about why.  You deserve all information pertaining to your pregnancy.  I've never ever heard of that before!  I wouldn't pay for it.

I had GD with my first pregnancy, but no insulin (controlled by diet and testing several times/day and keeping records).They are obviously concerned about your levels.  I'd ask your doctor the questions you are asking here and if you still aren't satisfied, ask to be referred to an endocrinologist for a second opinion.
I was insulin-dependant when I had GD but I was never admitted. That's a highly unusual practice. How far along are you?
i feel so sorry for you lot that have to pay for your healthcare, it must be such a strain and more stress added to everything. Im so glad im in London and dont have to pay for any of it. xx
